result.execSummary:
This case is being appealed. If the court makes a decision in a case that a party disagrees with, the party may have the right to seek review by a higher court to determine if the trial court's decision was correct. Appeals are most often made after a trial or final decision in a case, but an appeal can also occur before a final decision.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: The Court ordered that all court costs and fines be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision.
Defendant shall maintain full time employment.  Should defendant become unemployed he shall apply at 30 businesses/month that are hiring and file work search affidavits.
No use or possession of controlled substances, unless prescribed by a physician.   No possession of drug paraphernalia.

Complete compas assessment,  counseling, evaluations, programs and assessments as appropriate and followup.  Pay supervisory fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.  Defendant shall provide a DNA sample by calling the Work Release Unit  at 920-232-1915 or 920-232-1919 WITHIN 72 HOURS OF SENTENCING to set up an appointment.   The Work Release Units hours are 8:00 am-4:00 pm/Monday thru Friday. Defendant shall provide proof of identification along with the court minutes stating a DNA sample is required.  Failure to comply with this order may result in either a finding of contempt of court or a criminal charge of Failure to Provide a DNA Sample pursuant to Wis. Stats. 946.52.
**PURSUANT TO HEARING HELD ON 05-13-16, COURT ORDERS RESTITUTION TO BE PAID DURING THE TERM OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION**
